questions.question: What is the standard length of a full-size croquet court?

correctTheory.title: Standard Court Dimensions
correctTheory.author: Laws of Association Croquet
correctTheory.summary: The standard court size was established as 35 yards by 28 yards, with specific requirements for the playing surface and boundary markings.
correctTheory.significance: Standardization of court dimensions was crucial for tournament play and consistent rules across different venues

questions.question: Who is credited with standardizing the rules of croquet in the 1860s?

correctTheory.title: First Standardized Rules of Croquet
correctTheory.author: Walter Jones Whitmore
correctTheory.key_concepts: Rule standardization, competitive play, game formalization
correctTheory.summary: Whitmore published 'Croquet: The Laws and Regulations of the Game,' which became the foundation for modern croquet rules.
correctTheory.significance: First comprehensive rulebook that standardized competitive play
correctTheory.related_concepts: Tournament regulations, game variations, competitive formats

questions.citation: Whitmore, W.J. (1866). Croquet: The Laws and Regulations of the Game

questions.question: What is the 'triple peel'?

answers.answer: Running three hoops with the same ball in one turn
Peeling a ball through its last three hoops while going out
Scoring three points in one turn

correctTheory.title: Advanced Peeling Techniques
correctTheory.author: Various Champions
correctTheory.summary: The triple peel is an advanced tactic where a player peels their partner ball through its last three hoops while completing their own break to win the game.
correctTheory.significance: Demonstrates highest level of tactical play in Association Croquet
correctTheory.related_concepts: Break play, peeling, advanced tactics, game endings

questions.citation: Fulford, R. (2020). Peeling Techniques in Association Croquet
